content: Austronesian language, spoken by the Minangkabau of West Sumatra **Minangkabau** (/ˌmēnäŋkəˈbau̇/ *MEE-nahng-kah-bow*; *Baso Minangkabau*, [Jawi](/wiki/Jawi_script): بهاس منڠكربو‎, IPA: [ˈbaso mi.naŋˈka.bau]), simply known as **Minang**, is an [Austronesian language](/wiki/Austronesian_languages) spoken by the [Minangkabau](/wiki/Minangkabau_people) of [West Sumatra](/wiki/West_Sumatra), the western part of [Riau](/wiki/Riau), the southern and western coast of [Aceh](/wiki/Aceh), the northern part of [Bengkulu](/wiki/Bengkulu) and [Jambi](/wiki/Jambi), also in several cities throughout Indonesia by migrated Minangkabau. The language is also a [lingua franca](/wiki/Lingua_franca) along the western coastal region of the province of [North Sumatra](/wiki/North_Sumatra), and is even used in parts of Aceh, where it is known as the [Aneuk Jamee dialect](/wiki/Jamee_language). Minangkabau is similar to [Malay](/wiki/Malay_language). The relationship between the languages is characterized in different ways. Some see Minangkabau as an early variety of Malay, while others think of Minangkabau as a distinct ([Malayic](/wiki/Malayic_language)) language. Minangkabau is one of a few languages that generally lacks [verb forms](/wiki/Grammatical_conjugation) and grammatical subject-object distinctions.[*page needed*] The Minangkabau language is still commonly spoken amongst the Minangkabau people, and it is used amongst the widespread [Minangkabau diaspora](/wiki/Minangkabau_diaspora). The Minangkabau language is deemed as "informal" in the urban regions of [Padang](/wiki/Padang), with the [Indonesian language](/wiki/Indonesian_language) being preferred instead in formal institutions. Youth in the city frequently uses a mixture of conversational Minang and [Indonesian slang](/wiki/Indonesian_slang). ## Geographic distribution Minangkabau is the native language of the [Minangkabau people](/wiki/Minangkabau_people) of [West Sumatra](/wiki/West_Sumatra). There are approximately 5.5 million speakers of the language. It is also spoken in the western part of [Riau](/wiki/Riau), the southern and western coast of [Aceh](/wiki/Aceh), the northern part of [Bengkulu](/wiki/Bengkulu) and [Jambi](/wiki/Jambi). Along the western coastal region of [North Sumatra](/wiki/North_Sumatra), the language is also a [lingua franca](/wiki/Lingua_franca). The language is used and called *Aneuk Jamee* in parts of [Aceh](/wiki/Aceh). Besides Indonesia, Minangkabau is also spoken in Malaysia, by some descendants of migrants from the Minang-speaking region in Sumatra (*Ranah Minang*, *Tanah Minang*, or Land of the Minang). Significant numbers of the early migrants settled in what is now the Malaysian state of [Negeri Sembilan](/wiki/Negeri_Sembilan); this *[Negeri Sembilan Malay](/wiki/Negeri_Sembilan_Malay)*, known as *Bahaso Nogori / Baso Nogoghi*, is now a distinct language, more closely related to Malay than to Minangkabau. More recent immigrants are known as *Minang*. ## Dialects The Minangkabau language has several dialects, sometimes differing between nearby villages (e.g. separated by a river). The dialects are Rao Mapat Tunggul, Muaro Sungai Lolo, Payakumbuh, Pangkalan-Lubuk Alai, Agam-Tanah Datar, Pancungsoal, Kotobaru, Sungai Bendung Air, and Karanganyar. In everyday communication between Minangkabau people of different regions, the Agam-Tanah Datar dialect (*Baso Padang* or *Baso Urang Awak* 'our [people's] language') is often used and has become a kind of standard. The Tapan language, spoken in the town of Tapan in southern [West Sumatra](/wiki/West_Sumatra) province, is a recently discovered [Malayan language](/wiki/Malayan_languages) which has been proposed as related to but not part of Minangkabau. Together, Tapan and Minangkabau would form a Greater Minangkabau subgroup. The two languages Tapan and [Muko-Muko](/wiki/Muko-Muko_language) form a *Lunangic* subgroup within the *Minangic* (Greater Minangkabau) language group. The Minangic subgroup is characterized by the following word-final sound changes. - *V[hi]ŋ > V[hi]ăŋ - *us > uĭh - *at > eʔ - *as > eh - *is > ih ## Phonology The sound inventory of Minangkabau is listed below: ### Consonants [Labial](/wiki/Labial_consonant)[Alveolar](/wiki/Alveolar_consonant)[Palatal](/wiki/Palatal_consonant)[Velar](/wiki/Velar_consonant)[Glottal](/wiki/Glottal_consonant)[Nasal](/wiki/Nasal_consonant)[m](/wiki/Voiced_bilabial_nasal) ⟨m⟩[n](/wiki/Voiced_alveolar_nasal) ⟨n⟩[ɲ](/wiki/Voiced_palatal_nasal) ⟨ny⟩[ŋ](/wiki/Voiced_velar_nasal) ⟨ng⟩[Plosive](/wiki/Plosive)/ [Affricate](/wiki/Affricate)voiceless[p](/wiki/Voiceless_bilabial_plosive) ⟨p⟩[t](/wiki/Voiceless_alveolar_plosive) ⟨t⟩[tʃ](/wiki/Voiceless_postalveolar_affricate) ⟨c⟩[k](/wiki/Voiceless_velar_plosive) ⟨k⟩[ʔ](/wiki/Glottal_stop) ⟨k⟩, ⟨ʼ⟩voiced[b](/wiki/Voiced_bilabial_plosive) ⟨b⟩[d](/wiki/Voiced_alveolar_plosive) ⟨d⟩[dʒ](/wiki/Voiced_postalveolar_affricate) ⟨j⟩[ɡ](/wiki/Voiced_velar_plosive) ⟨g⟩[Fricative](/wiki/Fricative)[s](/wiki/Voiceless_alveolar_fricative) ⟨s⟩[h](/wiki/Voiceless_glottal_fricative) ⟨h⟩[Lateral](/wiki/Lateral_consonant)[l](/wiki/Voiced_alveolar_lateral_approximant) ⟨l⟩[Rhotic](/wiki/Rhotic_consonant)[r](/wiki/Voiced_alveolar_trill) ⟨r⟩[Semivowel](/wiki/Semivowel)[w](/wiki/Voiced_labial%E2%80%93velar_approximant) ⟨w⟩[j](/wiki/Voiced_palatal_approximant) ⟨y⟩ ### Vowels Monophthongs [Front](/wiki/Front_vowel)[Central](/wiki/Central_vowel)[Back](/wiki/Back_vowel)[Close](/wiki/Close_vowel)[i](/wiki/Close_front_unrounded_vowel) ⟨i⟩[u](/wiki/Close_back_rounded_vowel) ⟨u⟩[Mid](/wiki/Mid_vowel)[e](/wiki/Close-mid_front_unrounded_vowel) ⟨e⟩[o](/wiki/Close-mid_back_rounded_vowel) ⟨o⟩[Open](/wiki/Open_vowel)[a](/wiki/Open_front_unrounded_vowel) ⟨a⟩Diphthongs [Front](/wiki/Front_vowel)[Back](/wiki/Back_vowel)[Close](/wiki/Close_vowel)iə̯⁓ie̯ ⟨ia⟩uə̯⁓uo̯ ⟨ua⟩, ui̯ ⟨ui⟩[Mid](/wiki/Mid_vowel)eə̯ ⟨ea⟩oə̯ ⟨oa⟩[Open](/wiki/Open_vowel)ai̯ ⟨ai⟩, au̯ ⟨au⟩ ##
